title: 114_s1446
content: The "SOAR to Health and Wellness Act of 2015" defines human trafficking and establishes a pilot program under the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary will establish a pilot program called "SOAR to Health and Wellness Training" to provide training to healthcare providers on identifying and assisting human trafficking victims in compliance with all relevant laws. The pilot program "SOAR to Health and Wellness Training" will train healthcare providers to identify and assist human trafficking victims in compliance with legal confidentiality requirements. Care for victims should be coordinated, victim-centered, culturally relevant, comprehensive, evidence-based, gender-responsive, age-appropriate, and trauma-informed. Training programs for victims should also be integrated with existing programs. The pilot program established under this Act aims to assist victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, stalking, child abuse, neglect, maltreatment, and sexual exploitation. It includes functions from the Stop, Observe, Ask, and Respond to Health and Wellness Training program and engages stakeholders to develop flexible training initiatives. The pilot program aims to assist victims of various forms of abuse and exploitation. It includes developing flexible training modules that adapt to changing needs and providing grants for training in diverse healthcare settings. Technical assistance is also offered for nationwide health education programs. The pilot program aims to implement nationwide health care protocols, develop training materials, incentivize their utilization, and collect data on human trafficking victims in healthcare settings. The program will terminate on October 1, 2021. SEC. 4. DATA COLLECTION AND REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. During fiscal years 2016 through 2020, the Secretary is required to collect data on the number of facilities and providers participating in the pilot program established under section 3(a). This includes tracking facilities operating before and after the enactment of the Act, as well as the number of trained healthcare providers each year. The Secretary is required to collect data on facilities and providers participating in the pilot program during fiscal years 2016 through 2020. A report on the data collected must be submitted to Congress within 90 days after the start of each fiscal year. Authorization of appropriations for $3,000,000 annually from 2016 to 2020.
